prompt_final_to_llm:
You are a comparative analyst. Compare major frameworks or schools of thought, specifying explicit historical information only when stated in the provided snippets. Never infer missing event years. Use numeric IEEE-style citations [1], [2], etc., for statements supported by the provided snippets. Each number corresponds to one unique PDF listed below. Multiple snippets originating from the same PDF share the same number. Never assign multiple citation numbers to the same source.

**Your final answer MUST end with a separate section titled 'References'.**
This section MUST list all unique PDFs exactly once, in the following strict format:
[n] FILENAME.pdf (YEAR)

Do not fabricate author names, journals, or article titles — only use the given filename and metadata year.

Temporal Attribution Rules:
1. You may ONLY use event years that appear explicitly in the snippet text.
2. If the snippet text explicitly contains a year (e.g., 'In the 1950s', 'In 1976'), treat that as the factual historical reference.
3. If a snippet DOES NOT contain an explicit event year, you MUST NOT guess, infer, approximate, or estimate any year.
   Instead, write exactly: '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
4. The metadata publication year indicates only when the PDF was published, not when the events occurred.
5. Never replace or override an explicit event year with a metadata year.
6. Never deduce approximate historical periods from textual content (e.g., never infer '1990s' unless explicitly stated).

Output Structuring Guidelines:
- For every key historical or conceptual point:
  • If an explicit event year exists in the snippet → include it.
  • If no explicit event year exists → write '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
- Recommended dual-year structure:
  • (1950s; described in 2025 PDF [7]) The Turing Test was proposed as a benchmark.
This dual timestamping ensures full temporal grounding without hallucination.

IMPORTANT:
**Your output MUST end with a final section titled 'References'.**
This section must list all unique PDFs exactly once in IEEE numeric format.

Compare and contrast the main theoretical perspectives on explain the emergence of hybrid ai models in the corpus., grounding historical claims only in explicit snippet content.

Context snippets:
[1] A Survey on Large Language Model-based Agents for Statistics and Data Science.pdf (2025)
. The rise and potential of generative AI, particularly Large Language Models (LLMs) or vision language models (VLMs) in the field of data science and analysis have gained increasing recognition in recent years.

[2] D14-1162.pdf (2014)
. Our model efficiently leverages statistical information by training only on the nonzero elements in a word-word cooccurrence matrix, rather than on the entire sparse matrix or on individual context windows in a large corpus. The model produces a vector space with meaningful substructure, as evidenced by its performance of 75% on a recent word analogy task. . It also outperforms related models on similarity tasks and named entity recognition. . Semantic vector space models of language represent

. A meaningful exploration of both topics through the lens of Trustworthy AI (TAI),

We analyze and make explicit the model properties needed for such regularities to emerge in word vectors. . retrieved_chunks.query: Compare and contrast the main theoretical perspectives on explain the emergence of hybrid ai models in the corpus., grounding historical claims only in explicit snippet content.

model_output:
The emergence of hybrid AI models can be traced back to the 2014 introduction of a global logbilinear regression model that combined properties from two major model families, as described in [2]. This model was designed to capture fine-grained semantic and syntactic regularities using vector arithmetic. In recent years, there has been increasing recognition of the potential and rise of generative AI, particularly Large Language Models (LLMs) or vision language models (VLMs), in the field of data science and analysis [1]. However, explicit historical information about the emergence of these specific hybrid models is not provided in the given context. Moreover, the context does not provide enough evidence to determine if supervised or zero-shot models were predominantly used during the emergence of hybrid AI models. [3] discusses the significance of trustworthy AI (TAI) and machine generated text detection, while [4] highlights the challenges in reasoning tasks for intelligent AI models, but neither document provides direct insights into the historical development of hybrid AI models. References:
[1] A Survey on Large Language Model-based Agents for Statistics and Data Science.pdf (2025)
[2] D14-1162.pdf (2014)
[3] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
[4] 3641289.pdf (2024)
